question: Who invented the World Wide Web?

ctxs.title: Internet_History
ctxs.text: The history of the internet dates back to the 1960s.

ctxs.title: World Wide Web
ctxs.text: Tim Berners-Lee is credited with inventing the World Wide Web, a major component of the internet.

ctxs.title: Vint_Cerf
ctxs.text: Vint Cerf is known as one of the 'fathers of the internet' for his work on TCP/IP protocols.

ctxs.title: ARPANET
ctxs.text: The ARPANET project, funded by the US Department of Defense, was a precursor to the modern internet.

ctxs.title: Inventors
ctxs.text: Many individuals contributed to the development of the internet, including Tim Berners-Lee and Vint Cerf.

question: What is the position of Minqi Xiang from Hubei, at Imperial College London?

ctxs.title: Minqi
ctxs.text: Minqi Xiang comes from Hubei and is a MSc student at Imperial College London.

ctxs.title: Hubei
ctxs.text: Hubei is a province in China.

ctxs.title: minqi

ctxs.title: minchi
ctxs.text: Minchi Z is a cook in France!

ctxs.title: min5
ctxs.text: Min Xiang works as an engineer in Germany.

ctxs.title: Henry Feilden (Conservative politician)
ctxs.text: Henry Master Feilden (21 February 1818 – 5 September 1875) was an English Conservative Party politician.

ctxs.title: Feilden
ctxs.text: Bernard Feilden (1919–2008), British conservation architect; Bob Feilden (1917–2004), British mechanical engineer; Gerry Feilden (1904–1981), British general and horse racing identity; Henry Feilden (disambiguation); Joseph Feilden (1824–1895), British politician; Richard Feilden (1950–2005), British architect; William Feilden (1772–1850), British politician.

ctxs.title: Feilden baronets
ctxs.text: Henry Wemyss Feilden, second son of the second Baronet, was an Arctic explorer.

ctxs.title: Bernard Feilden
ctxs.text: Feilden was born in Hampstead, London. He was educated at Bedford School and The Bartlett School of Architecture, University College, London, completing his training at the Architectural Association after the second world war. His love of architecture was inherited from his grandfather, Brightwen Binyon (1846-1905), an Ipswich architect and former pupil of Alfred Waterhouse. He joined the practice of Edward Boardman and Son in Norwich, where he designed the Trinity United Reformed Church. He set up an architectural practice, Feilden+Mawson, with David Mawson in 1956, to which offices in Norwich, London and Cambridge were later added. In 1968 Feilden took over as consultant architect to the University.

ctxs.title: Henry Wemyss Feilden
ctxs.text: Colonel Henry Wemyss Feilden, CB (6 October 1838 – 8 June 1921) was a British Army officer, Arctic explorer and naturalist.
